mnd11:2.1: "Where are there many quarrels and arguments": "Quarrels" are quarrels based on
mnd11:2.2: one behavior, and "arguments" are the same. Anyone who argues, it is a quarrel;
mnd11:2.3: whoever argues, it is an argument. Or, in another way, arguing is called the
mnd11:2.4: first part of the quarrel. King arguing with king, khattiya arguing with
mnd11:2.5: khattiya, Brāhmaṇa arguing with Brāhmaṇa, homeowner arguing with homeowner,
mnd11:2.6: mother arguing with son, son arguing with mother, father arguing with son, son
mnd11:2.7: arguing with father, brother arguing with brother, brothers argue with sisters,
mnd11:2.8: sisters argue with brothers, friends argue with friends [MN.13]. What is a
mnd11:2.9: quarrel? Those who are keen on clubs at home quarrel with their bodies and
mnd11:2.10: words, and those who violate precepts quarrel with their bodies and words.
mnd11:3.1: "Where are there many quarrels and arguing": "Where are there many quarrels and
mnd11:3.2: quarrels? Where are they born? Where are they arising? Where are they generated?
mnd11:3.3: What are their causes? What is the collection? What is its birth? What is its
mnd11:3.4: root?" He inquired about the root of quarrel and argument; he inquired about the
mnd11:3.5: reason; he inquired about the cause; he inquired about the arising; he inquired
mnd11:3.6: about the generation; he inquired and waited; he inquired about the nutriment;
mnd11:3.7: he inquired about the fate; he inquired about the collection, he forcefully
mnd11:3.8: inquired, begged, requested, and asked for it to be made clear.
mnd11:4.1: "Weeping, sorrow and stinginess": "Weeping," being touched by the loss of the
mnd11:4.2: relatives..., who have lamenting, weeping, crying, grief, lamenting, speech,
mnd11:4.3: useless words, muttering, tearing, weeping state. "Sorrow," being touched by the
mnd11:4.4: loss of relatives, or the loss of property, ...from disease, ...of precepts,
mnd11:4.5: ...of sight; having certain losses, contact with certain sufferings; having a
mnd11:4.6: state of sorrow, sadness, grief, internal sorrow, internal grief, burning,
mnd11:4.7: internal burning, and the arrow of the heart. "Stinginess," there are five types
mnd11:4.8: of stinginess: stingy in dwelling, in home, of gain, of praise, of Dhamma,
mnd11:4.9: stingy appearance, stingy state, greed, miserly, petty, and heart-tight state
mnd11:4.10: are called stingy. In addition, miserliness is also stingy; world stinginess is
mnd11:4.11: also stingy; stinginess in views is also stingy. With this stinginess and
mnd11:4.12: intolerance, people become illiberal, so they are called stingy.

mnd11:20.2: stinginess": "Lovely," there are two types of lovely: sentient beings or deeds.
mnd11:20.3: What are lovely beings? Here, whoever is a mother, or father, or brother, or
mnd11:20.4: sister, or son, or daughter, or friend, or colleague, or relatives, who are of
mnd11:20.5: interest to him, or who want to be beneficial, or who want to stay away from the
mnd11:20.6: harness, or those with blood (kin), these are lovely beings. What are attractive

mnd11:21.3: sad when things they regard as their own are (feared to be) changed, they are
mnd11:21.4: also sad when they are changed, they are also sad when they have been changed;
mnd11:21.5: sad, tired, weeping, pounding their chests and crying, coming to chaos.

mnd11:22.2: conceited; depending on lovely things makes them arrogant. How does depending on
mnd11:22.3: lovely things make them conceited? "We are the recipients of desirable forms,
mnd11:22.4: sounds, smells, tastes, and touches." This is the production of conceit with
mnd11:22.5: lovely things. How does reliance on lovely things produce arrogance? "We are the
mnd11:22.6: recipients of the desired forms, ..., and these other people are not the
mnd11:22.7: recipients of the desired forms, ...." This is reliance on lovely things making
mnd11:23.1: "Quarrels and arguments are connected to stinginess": Quarrelling, arguing,

mnd11:24.3: speaks there in order to separate these people, or after he hears from there, in

mnd11:24.5: of harmony, the spreader of division, the disagreeable, the speaker of disunity,
mnd11:24.6: the speaker of disagreement, this is called divisive speech.
